disclaimer: This information is compiled from DailyMed drug labeling and is for informational purposes only. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult a healthcare provider or pharmacist for clinical decisions.

on_label: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in patients aged 6 years and older
off_label: Fatigue in cancer or palliative care
Cognitive enhancement in traumatic brain injury

medications.mechanism_of_action: Blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine into the presynaptic neuron and increases the release of these monoamines into the extraneuronal space. The d-threo enantiomer is the more pharmacologically active isomer.
medications.time_to_max_concentration: 6-10 hours (Concerta/OROS); 1-2 hours initial peak then 4-7 hours second peak (Ritalin LA/Metadate CD)
medications.half_life: 3.5 hours (Concerta); 6.8 hours (apparent, extended-release capsule formulations due to absorption-rate-limited elimination)
medications.active_metabolites: None clinically significant. Ritalinic acid (alpha-phenyl-piperidine acetic acid/PPA) is the primary metabolite but has little or no pharmacologic activity.
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: 3-4 hours (ritalinic acid, but not pharmacologically active)

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS stimulant effects; concurrent use of two stimulants increases risk of cardiovascular effects (hypertension, tachycardia), insomnia, and CNS overstimulation. Generally not prescribed together at full doses.
Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold; combined use with stimulants may further increase seizure risk. Additive dopaminergic and noradrenergic effects.
Methylphenidate may inhibit the metabolism of SSRIs. Rare risk of serotonin syndrome with combined serotonergic activity. Monitor for increased sertraline side effects.

Proton pump inhibitors may alter absorption characteristics of some extended-release methylphenidate formulations by changing gastric pH, though clinical significance is generally low for OROS formulations.
Opposing cardiovascular effects; propranolol may mitigate stimulant-induced tachycardia/hypertension. This combination is sometimes used therapeutically but requires monitoring.
Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Excessive caffeine may contribute to nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or tremor during concurrent use.
Methylphenidate can potentiate the pressor actions of vasopressors like ephedrine. Monitor cardiac function.

on_label: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in patients aged 6 years and older
off_label: Fatigue in cancer or palliative care

medications.mechanism_of_action: Blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine into the presynaptic neuron and increases the release of these monoamines into the extraneuronal space.
medications.active_metabolites: None clinically significant. Ritalinic acid is the primary metabolite but has little or no pharmacologic activity.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS stimulant effects; increased cardiovascular risk and CNS overstimulation.
Bupropion lowers seizure threshold; additive dopaminergic effects. Monitor for seizures and cardiovascular effects.
Methylphenidate may inhibit SSRIs metabolism. Monitor for serotonergic effects.
Opposing cardiovascular effects; may counteract stimulant-induced tachycardia.
Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Excessive caffeine may contribute to nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or tremor during concurrent use.
Methylphenidate can potentiate the pressor actions of vasopressors like ephedrine. Monitor cardiac function.

on_label: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in patients aged 6 years and older

medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-catecholamine sympathomimetic amine. Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine into presynaptic neurons and increases release of these monoamines into the extraneuronal space. Also has minor effects on serotonin. Contains d-amphetamine and l-amphetamine salts in a 3:1 ratio.
medications.active_metabolites: 4-hydroxyamphetamine, alpha-hydroxyamphetamine, norephedrine. These metabolites have some pharmacologic activity but contribute minimally to overall clinical effect at therapeutic doses.
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: Not well characterized independently; urinary elimination is pH-dependent

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS stimulant effects; increased risk of cardiovascular adverse events and CNS overstimulation.
Additive dopaminergic/noradrenergic effects. Bupropion lowers seizure threshold. Increased risk of seizures and cardiovascular effects.
Increased serotonergic activity; theoretical risk of serotonin syndrome. Monitor for symptoms.

Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acidity, which may shorten Tmax of amphetamine ER capsules (median Tmax shortened from 5 hours to 2.75 hours). May lead to earlier and higher peak concentrations.
Opposing cardiovascular effects. Propranolol may attenuate amphetamine-induced tachycardia and hypertension.
Trazodone may cause false-positive amphetamine screens. Additive effects on monoamine systems.
H2 blockers may raise gastric pH, potentially altering amphetamine absorption (though less effect than PPIs).
Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Patients should limit caffeine intake to avoid nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or tremor.
Cimetidine may raise gastrointestinal pH, potentially increasing amphetamine absorption and exacerbating stimulant effects.
Additive sympathomimetic effects. Increased cardiovascular risk (hypertension, tachycardia).

citations.title: Adderall XR (mixed salts of a single-entity amphetamine product) Extended-Release Capsules

medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-catecholamine sympathomimetic amine. Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine and increases release of monoamines. Contains d-amphetamine and l-amphetamine salts in a 3:1 ratio.
medications.active_metabolites: 4-hydroxyamphetamine, alpha-hydroxyamphetamine, norephedrine
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: Not well characterized independently; urinary elimination is pH-dependent

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS stimulant effects.
Additive dopaminergic effects; increased seizure risk.
Increased serotonergic activity; monitor for serotonin syndrome symptoms.
May alter amphetamine absorption by reducing gastric acidity.
Opposing cardiovascular effects.
Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Patients should limit caffeine intake to avoid nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or tremor.
Cimetidine may raise gastrointestinal pH, potentially increasing amphetamine absorption and exacerbating stimulant effects.
Additive sympathomimetic effects. Increased cardiovascular risk (hypertension, tachycardia).

citations.title: Adderall (mixed salts of a single-entity amphetamine product) Tablets

medications.mechanism_of_action: Partial agonist at serotonin 5-HT1A receptors (both presynaptic autoreceptors and postsynaptic receptors). Moderate affinity for brain D2 dopamine receptors. Does not bind to benzodiazepine receptors or affect GABA binding. Metabolized by CYP3A4.
medications.active_metabolites: 1-pyrimidinylpiperazine (1-PP) — potent alpha-2 adrenergic antagonist which may contribute to pharmacological effects. 6-hydroxybuspirone is also an active metabolite (5-HT1A partial agonist) with plasma levels 40-fold higher than parent.
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: 1-PP: approximately 6 hours; 6-hydroxybuspirone: data limited but longer than parent compound

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive serotonergic effects; theoretical risk of serotonin syndrome, though this combination is commonly used clinically for augmentation. Monitor for serotonin syndrome symptoms.
One report of concomitant use causing 3- to 6-fold elevations in SGPT (ALT). Additive serotonergic effects and theoretical serotonin syndrome risk. Monitor liver function.
In vitro studies show buspirone does not displace propranolol from plasma proteins. No significant pharmacokinetic interaction expected at therapeutic levels, but both may have additive CNS effects.
No significant known interaction.
No well-documented pharmacokinetic interaction. Both affect monoamine systems through different mechanisms.
Additive serotonergic effects; monitor for serotonin syndrome.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). Weakly inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. Does not inhibit monoamine oxidase. Mechanism of antidepressant activity is not fully understood. Also a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist. Is a potent CYP2D6 inhibitor.
medications.active_metabolites: Hydroxybupropion (primary, via CYP2B6), threohydrobupropion, erythrohydrobupropion. Hydroxybupropion has approximately half the potency of bupropion as an antidepressant.
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: Hydroxybupropion: ~20 hours; Threohydrobupropion: ~37 hours; Erythrohydrobupropion: ~33 hours

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive dopaminergic and noradrenergic effects. Bupropion lowers seizure threshold; use caution.
Additive dopaminergic effects. Increased seizure risk. Monitor cardiovascular parameters.
Bupropion is a potent CYP2D6 inhibitor and may increase sertraline levels. Monitor for increased SSRI side effects.
Bupropion (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase propranolol levels, as propranolol is partially metabolized by CYP2D6. Monitor for bradycardia and hypotension.
Bupropion is a potent CYP2D6 inhibitor and significantly increases dextromethorphan levels. Risk of DXM toxicity and serotonin syndrome. Avoid or use with extreme caution.
Bupropion may inhibit CYP2D6-mediated metabolism of trazodone (though trazodone is primarily CYP3A4-metabolized). Additive seizure risk.
Bupropion may inhibit CYP2D6-mediated metabolism of ondansetron. Clinical significance is uncertain.
Bupropion may lower seizure threshold; hydroxyzine at high doses may also lower seizure threshold. Additive risk.
Excessive caffeine may increase seizure risk with bupropion. Monitor for irritability, tremor, increased blood pressure, and insomnia.
Additive noradrenergic effects. Potential for increased blood pressure and seizure risk.

on_label: Primary hypercholesterolemia (elevated LDL cholesterol) as adjunct to diet
off_label: Diarrhea associated with Crohn's disease or ileal resection

medications.time_required_between_doses: 12 hours (given 1-2 times daily) or as a single daily dose
medications.mechanism_of_action: Bile acid sequestrant. Binds bile acids in the intestine to form an insoluble complex that is excreted in feces. This removes bile acids from the enterohepatic circulation, promoting hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids, ultimately lowering LDL cholesterol levels. Not absorbed systemically.
medications.time_to_max_concentration: Not applicable — colestipol is not absorbed systemically
medications.active_metabolites: None — not absorbed or metabolized systemically

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.drug: ALL other oral medications on this list
interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Colestipol can bind to and reduce absorption of virtually any co-administered oral medication. Other medications should be taken at least 1 hour before or 4 hours after colestipol to minimize this interaction. Specific concerns include:
May reduce sertraline absorption. Separate administration by at least 1 hour before or 4 hours after colestipol.
Colestipol may reduce propranolol absorption. Separate administration times.
Classic interaction — significantly reduces thyroid hormone absorption.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.
May reduce NSAID absorption. Separate dosing.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.
Colestipol may bind cimetidine in the GI tract, reducing its absorption. Separate dosing by at least 1-2 hours.

on_label: Male pattern hair loss/androgenetic alopecia (1mg dose)

medications.mechanism_of_action: Competitive and specific inhibitor of Type II 5-alpha reductase, an intracellular enzyme that converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Reduces serum and tissue DHT concentrations.
medications.half_life: 6 hours (range 3-16 hours); in elderly (>70 years): approximately 8 hours
medications.active_metabolites: Two metabolites have been identified (monohydroxylated and omega-carboxylic acid metabolites) with approximately 20% of finasteride's activity for 5-alpha reductase inhibition.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Colestipol may reduce finasteride absorption. Separate dosing times.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 640 mg/day (hypertension); varies by indication. Typical max for most indications: 320 mg/day
medications.time_required_between_doses: 6-12 hours (IR given 2-4 times daily); 24 hours (LA/ER formulations)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker (blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors). Reduces heart rate, myocardial contractility, blood pressure, and myocardial oxygen demand. Also has membrane-stabilizing activity. Metabolized primarily by CYP2D6 and CYP1A2.
medications.active_metabolites: 4-hydroxypropranolol — has beta-blocking activity comparable to propranolol. Formed via CYP2D6.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Opposing cardiovascular effects. Propranolol may mitigate stimulant-induced tachycardia/hypertension. Sometimes used deliberately.
Opposing cardiovascular effects. May counteract amphetamine-induced tachycardia.
Bupropion inhibits CYP2D6, potentially increasing propranolol levels. Monitor for excessive bradycardia and hypotension.
Sertraline is a moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor and may increase propranolol levels. Monitor heart rate and blood pressure.
Pseudoephedrine (sympathomimetic) may counteract propranolol's antihypertensive effects. Risk of unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation leading to hypertension.
Diphenhydramine inhibits CYP2D6 and may increase propranolol levels.
Additive hypotensive effects possible.
NSAIDs may reduce the antihypertensive effect of propranolol by inhibiting renal prostaglandin synthesis.
Colestipol may reduce propranolol absorption. Separate dosing.
No significant pharmacokinetic interaction documented. Propranolol is not significantly displaced by buspirone.
Caffeine may attenuate the antihypertensive and heart-rate lowering effects of propranolol.
Cimetidine (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase propranolol exposure, leading to increased risk of bradycardia and hypotension.
Concomitant use may antagonize the cardiovascular effects of either drug. Monitor hemodynamic parameters.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Potently and selectively inhibits neuronal reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) with minimal effects on norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake. Also moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6.
medications.active_metabolites: N-desmethylsertraline — approximately 1/8 as potent as sertraline for serotonin reuptake inhibition.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive serotonergic effects; increased risk of serotonin syndrome. Monitor for symptoms (agitation, hyperthermia, clonus, tremor).
Additive serotonergic effects; commonly used together for augmentation, but monitor for serotonin syndrome.
Serotonin syndrome risk.
Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 antagonist. Sertraline (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase ondansetron levels. Generally considered safe.
Sertraline inhibits CYP2D6, significantly increasing DXM levels. Increased risk of serotonin syndrome. Avoid or use with caution.
Bupropion (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase sertraline levels. Both affect monoamine systems.
Sertraline (moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase propranolol levels. Monitor heart rate and blood pressure.
Additive serotonergic effects. Commonly used together but monitor.
NSAIDs combined with SSRIs significantly increase risk of GI bleeding (3-6 fold increased risk). Use lowest effective NSAID dose and consider gastroprotection.
May reduce sertraline absorption. Separate dosing.
Additive sedation possible. Both may prolong QTc at higher doses.
Diphenhydramine inhibits CYP2D6 and may modestly increase sertraline levels. Additive sedation.
Additive sedation and serotonergic effects.
Cimetidine may modestly inhibit sertraline metabolism. Monitor for increased sertraline effects.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 400 mg/day (outpatient); 600 mg/day (inpatient) for depression. Typical insomnia dose: 25-100mg
medications.time_required_between_doses: For insomnia: once at bedtime. For depression: 8-12 hours (divided doses)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI). Inhibits serotonin reuptake and blocks 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors. Also blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors (causes orthostatic hypotension) and H1 histamine receptors (causes sedation). Metabolized primarily by CYP3A4.
medications.half_life: 5-9 hours (biphasic elimination: initial phase 3-6 hours, terminal phase 5-9 hours)
medications.active_metabolites: m-chlorophenylpiperazine (mCPP) — a serotonin agonist with anxiogenic and some serotonergic properties.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive serotonergic effects; increased risk of serotonin syndrome. Commonly co-prescribed (sertraline AM, trazodone for sleep) but monitor.
One report of 3-6 fold ALT elevations with concurrent use. Additive serotonergic effects.
Bupropion may inhibit CYP2D6 metabolism of trazodone. Additive seizure risk at high doses.
Additive serotonergic effects; risk of serotonin syndrome.
Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 antagonist; theoretical interaction with serotonergic agents. Generally safe.
Additive sedation when combined.
Additive CNS depression and sedation. Use caution.
Additive sedation and CNS depression.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation and CNS depression.
Additive hypotensive effects (trazodone blocks alpha-1 receptors).
Trazodone may cause false-positive amphetamine urine screens.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 40 mg/day (standard); up to 240 mg/day for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
medications.time_required_between_doses: 24 hours (once daily, taken 30-60 minutes before a meal); 12 hours if twice daily dosing needed
medications.mechanism_of_action: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI). Suppresses gastric acid secretion by specific inhibition of the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme system (proton pump) at the secretory surface of the gastric parietal cell. Esomeprazole is the S-isomer of omeprazole. Blocks the final step of acid production. Metabolized by CYP2C19 and CYP3A4.
medications.half_life: 1-1.5 hours (but duration of antisecretory effect lasts up to 24 hours due to irreversible binding to proton pump)
medications.active_metabolites: None — metabolites (hydroxy and desmethyl metabolites) have no significant antisecretory activity

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: PPIs reduce gastric acidity, which may shorten Tmax of extended-release amphetamine capsules (median Tmax shortened from ~5 hours to ~2.75 hours), leading to earlier peak effect.
Dual acid suppression — generally redundant and not recommended. PPIs are superior to H2 blockers for sustained acid suppression.
Colestipol may bind esomeprazole and reduce absorption. Separate dosing.
Dual acid suppression is generally redundant. If both used, the H2 blocker at bedtime may help with nocturnal acid breakthrough.

citations.title: Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPI) - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf

on_label: Adjunct therapy for peptic ulcer disease (reduce symptoms)
Reversal of muscarinic effects of cholinergic agents (with neostigmine)
Chronic severe drooling in children with neurologic conditions (oral solution)
off_label: Reduction of oral/respiratory secretions in palliative care

medications.mechanism_of_action: Quaternary ammonium anticholinergic (muscarinic receptor antagonist). Blocks the action of acetylcholine at parasympathetic sites in smooth muscle, secretory glands, and the CNS (though poor CNS penetration due to quaternary structure). Reduces gastrointestinal motility, gastric acid secretion, salivation, and other secretions. Does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — >80% excreted as unchanged drug in urine

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, blurred vision, tachycardia, cognitive impairment).
Additive anticholinergic effects. Increased risk of anticholinergic toxicity.
Strongly additive anticholinergic effects — both are anticholinergic agents. High risk of anticholinergic toxicity.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Glycopyrrolate may cause tachycardia (vagolytic effect) which opposes propranolol's bradycardic effect.
Both may cause constipation. Additive GI slowing effects.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 400 mg/day (200mg BID); 800 mg/day for familial adenomatous polyposis
medications.time_required_between_doses: 12-24 hours (once or twice daily depending on indication)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor. Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis primarily by inhibiting COX-2. Has minimal COX-1 inhibition at therapeutic doses, which theoretically reduces GI toxicity compared to non-selective NSAIDs. Metabolized primarily by CYP2C9.
medications.active_metabolites: None — metabolites (carboxylic acid, glucuronide conjugates) are inactive

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: SSRIs + NSAIDs significantly increase GI bleeding risk (3-6 fold). Consider gastroprotection with PPI.
Avoid concurrent use of multiple NSAIDs — additive GI, renal, and cardiovascular risk with no added efficacy.
NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect of beta-blockers by inhibiting renal prostaglandin synthesis.
Esomeprazole provides gastroprotection — beneficial combination if NSAID use is necessary.
May reduce celecoxib absorption. Separate dosing.
Cimetidine inhibits CYP2C9, potentially increasing celecoxib levels. Clinical significance not fully established.

citations.title: Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf

medications.mechanism_of_action: Second-generation antihistamine. Long-acting selective peripheral H1 receptor antagonist. Active metabolite of loratadine. Has anti-inflammatory and antiallergic properties beyond histamine blockade. Non-sedating at recommended doses. Metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 (though poorly metabolized — most is eliminated unchanged).
medications.active_metabolites: 3-hydroxydesloratadine — has antihistaminic activity

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Desloratadine is the active metabolite of loratadine. Using both is redundant and increases total antihistamine load. Avoid concurrent use.
Taking multiple antihistamines is generally not recommended as it increases sedation risk without proportional efficacy benefit. However, some allergists combine different classes.
Additive antihistamine effects. First-generation antihistamines add significant sedation.
Additive antihistamine effects and sedation.
Additive antihistamine and sedative effects.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 100 mg/dose; 400 mg/day (adults, though lower doses typically used)
medications.mechanism_of_action: First-generation antihistamine (H1 receptor antagonist) with anticholinergic, anxiolytic, and sedative properties. Also has 5-HT2A receptor antagonist activity. Active metabolite is cetirizine. Metabolized by hepatic oxidation.
medications.active_metabolites: Cetirizine — a potent second-generation H1 antihistamine (the same drug sold as Zyrtec).

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive antihistamine, anticholinergic, and sedative effects. Increased risk of anticholinergic toxicity.
Additive anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, tachycardia).
Additive anticholinergic effects. Significant risk of anticholinergic toxicity.
Additive sedation and CNS depression.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation and anticholinergic effects.
Cetirizine is the active metabolite of hydroxyzine. Using both results in excessive antihistamine effect and is redundant.
Additive antihistamine effects.
Additive sedation. Both may prolong QTc at higher doses.
Additive hypotensive effects possible.
Both may lower seizure threshold at high doses.

on_label: Adjunctive therapy for peptic ulcer disease
off_label: Cramps/abdominal pain associated with GI disorders

medications.time_required_between_doses: 4 hours (or as needed, up to maximum daily dose)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Anticholinergic/antimuscarinic agent. The levo-isomer of atropine. Blocks the action of acetylcholine at parasympathetic (muscarinic) receptor sites including smooth muscle, secretory glands, and CNS. Reduces GI motility and secretions, relaxes smooth muscle spasm. Crosses the blood-brain barrier (unlike glycopyrrolate).
medications.active_metabolites: Tropic acid and tropine (minor, via hydrolysis) — minimal pharmacologic significance

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Strongly additive anticholinergic effects. Both are anticholinergics — significantly increased risk of anticholinergic toxicity.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Hyoscyamine may cause tachycardia (vagolytic) opposing propranolol's effect.
Additive constipation effects.
Additive GI slowing/constipation — combined anticholinergic and opioid receptor effects on gut motility. Risk of paralytic ileus.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Preferential COX-2 inhibitor (non-selective NSAID at higher doses). Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis by inhibiting cyclooxygenase-1 and -2, with some preferential COX-2 selectivity. Anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic. Metabolized by CYP2C9 and CYP3A4.
medications.active_metabolites: None — metabolites are inactive

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: SSRIs + NSAIDs significantly increase GI bleeding risk.
Do not combine multiple NSAIDs. Additive GI, renal, and cardiovascular toxicity.
NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect.
Gastroprotective benefit when co-administered.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.

citations.title: Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf

on_label: Prevention of nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy
Prevention of nausea and vomiting associated with radiation therapy
Prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 24 mg/day (oral); 16 mg single IV dose max
medications.mechanism_of_action: Selective 5-HT3 (serotonin type 3) receptor antagonist. Blocks serotonin at 5-HT3 receptors both peripherally (on vagal nerve terminals) and centrally (in the chemoreceptor trigger zone). Metabolized by CYP3A4, CYP1A2, and CYP2D6.
medications.time_to_max_concentration: 2 hours (oral); 15-30 minutes (ODT, though similar to oral)
medications.half_life: 3-6 hours (adults); may be prolonged in hepatic impairment
medications.active_metabolites: None clinically significant

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Both affect serotonin pathways. Sertraline (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may modestly increase ondansetron levels. Generally safe combination.
Both affect serotonin pathways. Generally safe but monitor.
Bupropion (CYP2D6 inhibitor) may modestly increase ondansetron levels.
Additive constipation effects.
Additive constipation risk.
Both affect serotonin pathways. Low risk of interaction at typical doses.

on_label: Insomnia characterized by difficulty with sleep onset

medications.mechanism_of_action: Selective melatonin receptor agonist with high affinity for MT1 and MT2 receptors in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). Promotes sleep onset by mimicking melatonin's action on sleep-wake cycle regulation. No affinity for GABA receptors, opioid receptors, or other sedative targets. Not a controlled substance. Metabolized primarily by CYP1A2 and secondarily by CYP2C and CYP3A4.
medications.active_metabolites: M-II metabolite — has approximately 1/10 to 1/5 the binding affinity of ramelteon for MT1/MT2 receptors and circulates at 20-100x higher levels than parent compound. May contribute to overall clinical effect.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive sedation.
Additive sedation. Both are sleep aids — using both is generally redundant.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
No significant pharmacokinetic interaction. Minimal additive sedation.
Major interaction — cimetidine inhibits CYP3A4 and CYP1A2, which metabolize ramelteon. May significantly increase ramelteon exposure.

on_label: Insomnia (short-term treatment for difficulty falling asleep)
off_label: Middle-of-the-night awakenings (when at least 4 hours of sleep remain)

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 20 mg/day; 5 mg recommended for elderly/debilitated patients
medications.time_required_between_doses: Should only be taken once per night. Not for middle-of-night redosing unless 4+ hours remain before waking.
medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-benzodiazepine hypnotic (pyrazolopyrimidine class). Selectively binds to the omega-1 (BZ1) subunit of the GABA-A receptor complex, enhancing GABAergic inhibition. More selective for sleep-inducing effects with minimal anxiolytic, muscle relaxant, or anticonvulsant properties. Primarily metabolized by aldehyde oxidase and CYP3A4.
medications.time_to_max_concentration: 1 hour (reduced to 2 hours with high-fat meal)
medications.active_metabolites: None — primary metabolites (5-oxo-zaleplon and desethylzaleplon) are inactive

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS depression and sedation.
Additive sedation. Combining two sleep aids is generally redundant.
Additive CNS depression.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
Minimal direct interaction. Monitor for additive sedation.
Additive CNS depression at higher doses. Generally minimal interaction.
Major interaction — cimetidine inhibits aldehyde oxidase and CYP3A4 (zaleplon's metabolic pathways), increasing zaleplon exposure by 85%. Reduce zaleplon dose to 5 mg.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 40 mg/day (OTC use: 20 mg BID); 160 mg every 6 hours for hypersecretory conditions
medications.mechanism_of_action: Competitive, reversible inhibitor of histamine H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells. Reduces basal and stimulated gastric acid secretion, including nocturnal acid secretion. Does not affect CYP450 enzymes significantly.
medications.active_metabolites: None — famotidine S-oxide is the primary metabolite and is inactive

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Dual acid suppression is generally redundant. If both used, H2 blocker at bedtime may help with nocturnal acid breakthrough on PPI therapy.
May modestly raise gastric pH, potentially affecting amphetamine ER absorption (less effect than PPIs).
Colestipol may bind famotidine. Separate dosing.
Both are H2-receptor antagonists; concurrent use is redundant and provides no additional benefit.

on_label: Chronic diarrhea associated with inflammatory bowel disease (Rx)

medications.time_required_between_doses: After each loose stool, minimum 2 hours between doses
medications.mechanism_of_action: Synthetic opioid that acts on mu-opioid receptors in the intestinal wall. Slows intestinal motility, prolongs transit time, and reduces fecal volume. Increases anal sphincter tone. Does not significantly cross the blood-brain barrier at therapeutic doses (P-glycoprotein substrate), so no central opioid effects.
medications.active_metabolites: N-demethyl loperamide — minimal clinical significance at therapeutic doses

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive GI slowing. Increased risk of constipation, ileus, or toxic megacolon.
Additive GI slowing and anticholinergic effects.
Additive constipation.
Additive constipation and anticholinergic effects.

on_label: Relief of pressure, bloating, and fullness from excess gas in the GI tract
off_label: Adjunct for bowel preparation before colonoscopy/endoscopy
Relief of colic symptoms in infants (drops formulation)

medications.mechanism_of_action: Antifoaming agent. Changes the surface tension of gas bubbles in the GI tract, causing them to coalesce into larger bubbles that can be more easily passed by belching or flatulence. Is chemically inert, not absorbed systemically, and has no pharmacological activity.
medications.half_life: Not applicable — not absorbed systemically. Passes through GI tract unchanged.
medications.active_metabolites: None — not absorbed or metabolized

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: No known clinically significant drug interactions. Simethicone is inert and not absorbed.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-selective NSAID. Inhibits both cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis. Provides anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic effects. Metabolized by CYP2C9 and CYP2C8.
medications.active_metabolites: None — metabolites are inactive hydroxylated and conjugated compounds

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: SSRIs + NSAIDs significantly increase GI bleeding risk (3-6 fold).
Avoid concurrent use of multiple NSAIDs.
NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect.
PPI provides gastroprotection during NSAID use.
H2 blocker provides partial gastroprotection.
May reduce ibuprofen absorption. Separate dosing.
Can be used together alternately for additive analgesia. Different mechanisms of action. Generally safe combination.

citations.title: Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 4000 mg/day (healthy adults); 2000-3000 mg/day recommended for chronic use or those with liver disease or alcohol use
medications.mechanism_of_action: Exact mechanism not fully understood. Thought to inhibit COX enzymes centrally (in the brain/spinal cord) rather than peripherally, reducing prostaglandin synthesis in the CNS. May also involve activation of descending serotonergic pathways and interaction with the endocannabinoid system via its metabolite AM404. Minimal anti-inflammatory activity. Metabolized primarily by hepatic glucuronidation and sulfation; minor pathway via CYP2E1 produces hepatotoxic metabolite NAPQI.
medications.active_metabolites: AM404 (formed in the CNS, interacts with endocannabinoid system — contributes to analgesic effect). NAPQI is a toxic reactive metabolite (not therapeutic) normally detoxified by glutathione.
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: AM404: not well characterized systemically; NAPQI: rapidly conjugated with glutathione

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Can be safely alternated with NSAIDs for additive analgesia. Different mechanisms.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.
No significant interaction at standard doses.

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 1500 mg/day (Rx, naproxen base); 660 mg/day (OTC naproxen sodium, i.e., 220mg TID)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-selective NSAID. Inhibits COX-1 and COX-2, reducing prostaglandin synthesis. Anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic. Metabolized by CYP2C9 and CYP1A2.
medications.active_metabolites: None — 6-O-desmethyl naproxen is inactive

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: SSRIs + NSAIDs significantly increase GI bleeding risk.
Avoid concurrent NSAIDs.
NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect.
PPI provides gastroprotection.
May reduce absorption. Separate dosing.

citations.title: Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf

medications.mechanism_of_action: Second-generation antihistamine. Long-acting selective peripheral H1 receptor antagonist. Metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 to its active metabolite desloratadine. Non-sedating at recommended doses.
medications.active_metabolites: Desloratadine — the same active ingredient as Clarinex. Equipotent antihistamine.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Desloratadine IS the active metabolite of loratadine. Using both is redundant. Avoid concurrent use.
Taking multiple antihistamines increases sedation risk. Generally not recommended.
Additive antihistamine effects. Increased sedation.
Additive antihistamine effects.
Both are CYP2D6 inhibitors and may theoretically increase loratadine levels, though clinical significance is minimal.

medications.mechanism_of_action: First-generation antihistamine (ethylamine class). Competitive H1 receptor antagonist with significant anticholinergic, sedative, and anti-emetic properties. Inhibits CYP2D6. Crosses the blood-brain barrier readily, causing CNS depression/sedation.
medications.half_life: 4-8 hours (adults); may be prolonged in elderly
medications.active_metabolites: N-desmethyldiphenhydramine and others — minimal clinical significance

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive antihistamine, anticholinergic, and sedative effects. High redundancy and toxicity risk.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive sedation.
Additive CNS depression.
Additive sedation.
Both are first-generation sedating antihistamines. Highly redundant and additive sedation.
Diphenhydramine inhibits CYP2D6 and may increase propranolol levels.
Additive sedation. DPH inhibits CYP2D6, may modestly increase sertraline levels.
Both inhibit CYP2D6. Additive CYP2D6 inhibition may increase levels of 2D6 substrates.
Additive constipation and anticholinergic effects.
Additive antihistamine effects. Generally avoid combining 1st and 2nd gen antihistamines routinely.
Additive CNS depression. Both are commonly combined in OTC cold products but monitor for excessive sedation.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Second-generation antihistamine. Selective peripheral H1 receptor antagonist. Active metabolite of hydroxyzine. Minimal anticholinergic activity. Low CNS penetration but can cause mild sedation in some patients. Primarily renally eliminated (minimal hepatic metabolism).
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — cetirizine itself is the active metabolite of hydroxyzine. Minimal further metabolism.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Cetirizine IS the active metabolite of hydroxyzine. Concurrent use results in excessive antihistamine effect. Avoid.
Multiple antihistamines generally not recommended.
Additive antihistamine and sedative effects.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation possible with cetirizine.

off_label: Chronic urticaria (higher doses up to 240mg BID)

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 180 mg/day (standard); up to 480 mg/day studied in chronic urticaria
medications.mechanism_of_action: Second-generation antihistamine. Selective peripheral H1 receptor antagonist. Active metabolite of terfenadine. Non-sedating — does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly. Not significantly metabolized hepatically. Primarily excreted unchanged in feces.
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — fexofenadine undergoes minimal metabolism

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.drug: Other antihistamines (Desloratadine, Loratadine, Cetirizine, Levocetirizine, Hydroxyzine, Diphenhydramine)
interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Multiple antihistamines generally not recommended, though fexofenadine is the least sedating.
May reduce fexofenadine absorption. Separate dosing.
Antacids containing aluminum/magnesium reduce fexofenadine absorption, but H2 blockers and PPIs do not significantly affect it.

medications.mechanism_of_action: Second-generation antihistamine. R-enantiomer of cetirizine with approximately twice the binding affinity for H1 receptors. Selective peripheral H1 receptor antagonist. Minimal metabolism — primarily excreted unchanged in urine.
medications.active_metabolites: None significant

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Levocetirizine IS the active R-enantiomer of cetirizine. Using both is redundant. Avoid concurrent use.
Both cetirizine and levocetirizine are metabolites of hydroxyzine. Redundant.
Multiple antihistamines generally not recommended.

on_label: Temporary relief of cough due to minor throat/bronchial irritation (common cold)
off_label: Pseudobulbar affect (in combination with quinidine as Nuedexta)

medications.time_required_between_doses: 4-8 hours (IR: every 4 hours; ER: every 12 hours)
medications.mechanism_of_action: Non-opioid antitussive. Acts centrally to elevate the cough threshold. NMDA receptor antagonist, sigma-1 receptor agonist, and serotonin reuptake inhibitor at higher doses. Also has weak affinity for opioid receptors. Metabolized primarily by CYP2D6 to dextrorphan (active metabolite with NMDA antagonist activity).
medications.half_life: 3-6 hours (extensive CYP2D6 metabolizers); up to 24+ hours in poor CYP2D6 metabolizers
medications.active_metabolites: Dextrorphan — NMDA receptor antagonist with significant pharmacological activity. Formed via CYP2D6.

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: CRITICAL: Sertraline (CYP2D6 inhibitor) significantly increases DXM levels. Both are serotonergic — high risk of serotonin syndrome. Avoid or use with extreme caution.
CRITICAL: Bupropion is a potent CYP2D6 inhibitor and dramatically increases DXM levels (this mechanism is the basis for the drug Auvelity). Risk of serotonin syndrome and DXM toxicity.
Additive serotonergic effects. Risk of serotonin syndrome.
Additive serotonergic effects.
Additive CNS depression. Commonly combined in OTC products. Diphenhydramine also inhibits CYP2D6, increasing DXM levels.
Additive CNS depression.
Both affect serotonin pathways. Low risk at typical doses.

off_label: Nausea and vomiting of pregnancy (often combined with pyridoxine/B6 as Diclegis/Bonjesta)

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 25 mg per dose (as sleep aid); 75 mg/day for NVP (in combination with pyridoxine)
medications.time_required_between_doses: Once at bedtime (sleep aid); 8-12 hours for NVP indication
medications.mechanism_of_action: First-generation antihistamine (ethylamine class, same class as diphenhydramine). Competitive H1 receptor antagonist with significant anticholinergic and sedative properties. CNS penetration produces drowsiness.
medications.active_metabolites: N-desmethyldoxylamine and N,N-didesmethyldoxylamine — minimal clinical significance

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Both are first-generation sedating antihistamines. Highly redundant and strongly additive sedation.
Additive sedation and anticholinergic effects.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive anticholinergic effects.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation.
Additive sedation. Minor serotonergic interaction.
Additive CNS depression. Commonly combined in OTC products.
Additive antihistamine effects.

on_label: Nasal congestion due to common cold, sinusitis, or upper respiratory allergies

medications.mechanism_of_action: Sympathomimetic amine. Acts as an indirect-acting alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist by displacing norepinephrine from storage sites. Stimulates alpha-adrenergic receptors in nasal mucosa, producing vasoconstriction and reducing nasal congestion. Also has mild beta-adrenergic activity (bronchodilation, cardiac stimulation).
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — excreted primarily unchanged in urine (43-96% depending on urine pH)

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: IMPORTANT: Pseudoephedrine (sympathomimetic) may counteract propranolol's antihypertensive/cardiac effects. Risk of unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation causing severe hypertension, especially with non-selective beta-blockers like propranolol.
Additive sympathomimetic effects. Increased cardiovascular risk (hypertension, tachycardia).
Additive noradrenergic effects. Potential for increased blood pressure and seizure risk.
Additive CNS-stimulant and sympathomimetic effects; excessive caffeine may worsen nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or cardiac effects.
Both are sympathomimetic amines. Pseudoephedrine can potentiate the effects and increase the toxicity of ephedrine. Avoid concurrent use or use with extreme caution.

on_label: Expectorant for productive cough — helps loosen phlegm and thin bronchial secretions

medications.mechanism_of_action: Expectorant. Increases respiratory tract fluid secretions and helps to loosen phlegm and thin bronchial secretions by reducing the adhesiveness and surface tension of mucus, facilitating removal by coughing. Stimulates secretions from the submucosal glands of the respiratory tract. May also have some antitussive activity at higher doses.
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — metabolized to beta-(2-methoxyphenoxy) lactic acid (inactive) and excreted renally

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: No significant pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic interactions with other drugs on this list. Guaifenesin is generally well-tolerated with minimal drug interaction potential.
Available as a fixed-dose combination product (ephedrine/guaifenesin) for temporary relief of mild asthma symptoms with expectoration.

on_label: Restore mental alertness or wakefulness during fatigue or drowsiness
off_label: Migraine (adjunct, in combination with acetaminophen and aspirin)
Bronchopulmonary dysplasia prevention in premature infants

medications.maximum_daily_dosage: 400-600 mg/day (OTC alertness aid); 200 mg per dose, may repeat every 3-4 hours
medications.mechanism_of_action: Methylxanthine-class CNS stimulant. Antagonizes all four adenosine receptor subtypes (A1, A2a, A2b, A3); wakefulness is primarily driven by A2a antagonism. Also stimulates catecholamine release, exerts positive cardiac inotropic/chronotropic effects, increases gastric acid secretion, and promotes diuresis.
medications.half_life: Approximately 5 hours (adults); up to 15 hours in late pregnancy; up to 100 hours in premature neonates
medications.active_metabolites: Paraxanthine, theobromine, theophylline (all dimethylxanthines with unique pharmacological effects)
medications.half_life_of_active_metabolites: Paraxanthine ~3-4 hours; theobromine ~6-10 hours; theophylline ~3-7 hours

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Excessive caffeine may contribute to nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or tremor. Patients should limit caffeine intake while using stimulant medications.
Bupropion carries a dose-related seizure risk. Excessive caffeine (a psychostimulant) may increase this risk. Monitor for irritability, tremor, increased blood pressure, and insomnia.
Additive CNS-stimulant and cardiovascular effects. The combination was historically used for weight loss but carries risk of nervousness, irritability, insomnia, and cardiac arrhythmias.
Cimetidine (CYP1A2 inhibitor) may inhibit hepatic oxidative metabolism of caffeine, potentially increasing caffeine-related side effects. Caffeine dosage or intake may need to be reduced.
Additive CNS-stimulant effects. Both are sympathomimetics; excessive caffeine may worsen nervousness, irritability, insomnia, or cardiac effects.
Caffeine may attenuate the antihypertensive and heart-rate lowering effects of propranolol through opposing cardiovascular mechanisms.

off_label: Acid aspiration prophylaxis prior to anesthesia

medications.time_required_between_doses: 6-12 hours (dose dependent); 800 mg at bedtime for ulcer
medications.mechanism_of_action: Competitive H2-receptor antagonist. Blocks histamine from stimulating H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, reducing basal and stimulated gastric acid secretion. Also a non-selective inhibitor of hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes (CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2D6, CYP3A4), leading to numerous drug interactions.
medications.half_life: Approximately 2 hours; prolonged in renal impairment
medications.active_metabolites: None significant — cimetidine sulfoxide is the primary metabolite with minimal activity

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Cimetidine (weak CYP2D6 inhibitor) may increase propranolol exposure. Monitor for increased propranolol adverse reactions including bradycardia and hypotension.
H2-blockers may raise gastrointestinal pH, increasing amphetamine absorption and potentially exacerbating stimulant effects. Use with caution.
Major interaction — cimetidine inhibits CYP3A4 and CYP1A2, which metabolize ramelteon. Concurrent use may significantly increase ramelteon exposure and risk of adverse reactions.
Major interaction — reduce zaleplon initial dose to 5 mg with cimetidine. Cimetidine inhibits both aldehyde oxidase and CYP3A4, increasing zaleplon Cmax and AUC by 85%.
Cimetidine inhibits CYP2C9, which metabolizes celecoxib. May result in increased celecoxib levels, though clinical significance is not fully established.
Cimetidine (CYP1A2 inhibitor) may inhibit hepatic oxidative metabolism of caffeine. Caffeine dosage or intake may need to be reduced if caffeine-related side effects occur.
Dual acid suppression is generally redundant. If both used, the H2 blocker at bedtime may help with nocturnal acid breakthrough on PPI therapy.
Both are H2-receptor antagonists; concurrent use provides no additional benefit and is redundant. Use one or the other.
Cimetidine may modestly inhibit metabolism of sertraline (CYP2D6 substrate). Monitor for increased sertraline effects.
Colestipol may bind cimetidine in the GI tract, reducing its absorption. Separate dosing by at least 1-2 hours.

off_label: Hypotension during spinal or epidural anesthesia (including obstetric)

medications.mechanism_of_action: Mixed-acting sympathomimetic amine. Acts both directly on alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors and indirectly by inhibiting neuronal norepinephrine reuptake and displacing norepinephrine from storage vesicles. Produces vasoconstriction (alpha-1), increased cardiac chronotropy and inotropy (beta-1), and bronchodilation (beta-2). Stereoisomer of pseudoephedrine with more pronounced indirect mechanism.
medications.half_life: Approximately 6 hours (oral); urinary excretion is pH-dependent (shorter with acidic urine)
medications.active_metabolites: Norephedrine — the parent drug and metabolite are both excreted in urine

interactions_with_other_drugs_on_this_li.interaction: Concomitant use may antagonize the cardiovascular effects of either drug. Beta-blockade may reduce ephedrine's bronchodilatory and cardiac effects while ephedrine may counteract propranolol's antihypertensive effect. Monitor hemodynamic parameters.
Methylphenidate derivatives can potentiate the pressor actions of vasopressors like ephedrine. Additive sympathomimetic/cardiovascular effects. Monitor cardiac function.
Additive CNS-stimulant and cardiovascular effects. The combination may cause nervousness, irritability, insomnia, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Both are sympathomimetic amines. Pseudoephedrine can potentiate the effects and increase the toxicity of ephedrine by adding to sympathomimetic activity. Avoid concurrent use or use with extreme caution.
Additive noradrenergic effects. Potential for increased blood pressure and seizure risk.
Available as a fixed-dose combination product (ephedrine HCl 12.5 mg / guaifenesin 200 mg) for temporary relief of mild asthma symptoms with expectoration.
